results.title: Natalie Kalmus
results.brief_description: When studios hired Technicolor cameras and equipment, they also hired Natalie Kalmus. During the glory days of Technicolor’s three-strip process, between 1934 and 1955, she was the colour supervisor on over 400 films, including The Wizard of Oz (1939).

constellations_primary.name: Communicating colour
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of colour on-screen inspired by Technicolor supervisor, Natalie Kalmus.

results.description:
When studios hired Technicolor cameras and equipment, they also hired Natalie Kalmus. During the glory days of Technicolor’s three-strip process, between 1934 and 1955, she was the colour supervisor on over 400 films, including The Wizard of Oz (1939) and Gone with the Wind (1939).

After seeing filmmakers use the earlier two-strip Technicolor process to produce “unnatural and disastrous results”, she urged filmmakers to employ “colour restraint”. Kalmus believed that colour theories used in paintings could also be used in film and encouraged filmmakers to carefully consider which colours would convey a story’s emotions and themes.
description_for_label:
When studios hired Technicolor cameras and equipment, they also hired Natalie Kalmus. During the glory days of Technicolor’s three-strip process, between 1934 and 1955, she was the colour supervisor on over 400 films, including The Wizard of Oz (1939) and Gone with the Wind (1939).

After seeing filmmakers use the earlier two-strip Technicolor process to produce “unnatural and disastrous results”, she urged filmmakers to employ “colour restraint”. Kalmus believed that colour theories used in paintings could also be used in film and encouraged filmmakers to carefully consider which colours would convey a story’s emotions and themes.

results.title: Naphtali Faulkner's family home after the Black Summer fires hit Lismore
My Survival as an Aboriginal
results.credit_line: Courtesy the Coffey family and Martha Ansara / the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia / Ballad Films
results.brief_description: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture to her community.

constellations_primary.name: Black documentary and truth telling
constellations_primary.description: Essie Coffey was a trailblazer of Indigenous filmmaking, being the first Aboriginal woman to direct a documentary. The film spotlights the outspoken voice Coffey utilised to convey the realities faced by Aboriginal people and to encourage resistance to assimilation.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film
constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

results.description: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture – and the importance of cultural knowledge – to her community. Importantly, her documentary also exposed how First Peoples were marginalised in all aspects of their lives, from school to wider society. The treatment of First Peoples laid bare in her documentary reached wider audiences through screenings at prestigious Australian and international film festivals, where the film won numerous awards. For her dedicated services to the Indigenous Australian community, Coffey herself was awarded an Order of Australia.
description_for_label: Essie Coffey OAM was a Murawarri activist, advocate and filmmaker concerned about the influence of white culture and education on Indigenous children. As seen in her groundbreaking documentary, My Survival as an Aboriginal (1978), she taught culture – and the importance of cultural knowledge – to her community. Importantly, her documentary also exposed how First Peoples were marginalised in all aspects of their lives, from school to wider society. The treatment of First Peoples laid bare in her documentary reached wider audiences through screenings at prestigious Australian and international film festivals, where the film won numerous awards. For her dedicated services to the Indigenous Australian community, Coffey herself was awarded an Order of Australia.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy the Coffey family and Martha Ansara / the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia / Ballad Films

results.title: My Brilliant Career
results.credit_line:
Courtesy Margaret Fink Films

Held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: A key work in the Australian New Wave film movement, My Brilliant Career was Gillian Armstrong’s first feature film and a global success, gaining Academy Award and Palme d’Or nominations.

constellations_primary.name: Page to screen
constellations_primary.description: Australian scribes and screenwriters unite on the silver and small screens.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

constellations_other.name: Brilliant careers (Gillian Armstrong)
constellations_other.description: Gillian Armstrong's feature film debut not only helped launch her own acclaimed career, but those of the actors as well.

results.description:
Aunt Helen (Wendy Hughes) was wrong when she told Sybylla (Judy Davis) that her “wildness of spirit” would get her in trouble her whole life. It’s Sybylla’s independence and defiance that frees her from 19th-century Australia’s repressive, patriarchal society in Gillian Armstrong’s My Brilliant Career (1979).

A key work in the Australian New Wave film movement, My Brilliant Career was Armstrong’s first feature film and a global success, gaining Academy Award and Palme d’Or nominations.

Adapted from Stella Miles Franklin’s 1901 novel of the same name, the film certainly reflected the author’s feminist spirit: key roles in its production were held by women, including producer Margaret Fink, production designer Luciana Arrighi and costume designer Anna Senior.
description_for_label:
Aunt Helen (Wendy Hughes) was wrong when she told Sybylla (Judy Davis) that her “wildness of spirit” would get her in trouble her whole life. It’s Sybylla’s independence and defiance that frees her from 19th-century Australia’s repressive, patriarchal society in Gillian Armstrong’s My Brilliant Career (1979).

A key work in the Australian New Wave film movement, My Brilliant Career was Armstrong’s first feature film and a global success, gaining Academy Award and Palme d’Or nominations.

Adapted from Stella Miles Franklin’s 1901 novel of the same name, the film certainly reflected the author’s feminist spirit: key roles in its production were held by women, including producer Margaret Fink, production designer Luciana Arrighi and costume designer Anna Senior.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

results.title: Music cue sheets
results.brief_description: In the silent era, studios began to create cue sheets that charted the major moments of a motion picture, along with what kind of audio accompaniment was recommended to match the action on screen.

constellations_primary.name: Right on cue
constellations_primary.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.description: Although it was called the silent era, films of early cinema were never truly silent. From soaring scores performed by live orchestras to phonograph recordings, filmmakers were constantly searching for new ways to incorporate sound into the moving image. Studios began to create cue sheets that charted the major moments of a motion picture, along with what kind of audio accompaniment was recommended to match the action on screen. In Japan live musical accompaniment was complemented by benshi performers, who would provide live narration during a screening and helped silent films endure long after synchronised sound was introduced.
description_for_label: Although it was called the silent era, films of early cinema were never truly silent. From soaring scores performed by live orchestras to phonograph recordings, filmmakers were constantly searching for new ways to incorporate sound into the moving image. Studios began to create cue sheets that charted the major moments of a motion picture, along with what kind of audio accompaniment was recommended to match the action on screen. In Japan live musical accompaniment was complemented by benshi performers, who would provide live narration during a screening and helped silent films endure long after synchronised sound was introduced.

results.title: Murder in the Clouds cinema slide
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures and D. Lederman
results.credit_line: ACMI has endeavoured to contact the owners of these objects since their deposit in 2015. Unfortunately this has been unsuccessful. We would welcome any information to identify the owners.
results.brief_description: Two glass sheets: one glass only and the other with slide imagery which has a monochromatic emulsion that has then been hand painted with coloured pigments or dye. TEXT on the slide reads: Murder in the Clouds Mystery rides the air lanes Lyle Talbot Anne Dvorak Gordon Westcott Gunn Slide for general exhibition The two sheets of glass are held together using Gunn’s Slide branded tape: Gunn’s Slide, 9 Collins Place Melb. Cent. 2736

results.title: Ms Pac-Man arcade cabinet
results.creator_credit: Namco, Midway and General Computer Corporation
results.brief_description: Ms Pac-Man hit arcades in 1982 and featured the first famous female game protagonist, though she started out as male character. It featured new mazes and improved the unpredictability of enemies to make it more challenging.
results.description:
Ms Pac-Man is the first famous female game protagonist, but she started out as a male character. Designed by a group of Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) dropouts who started a company called the General Computer Corporation (GCC), Ms Pac-Man was originally a modification for the original Pac-Man, called Crazy Otto. Due to legal action by Atari, GCC presented their modification kit to the North American Pac-Man distributor, who purchased it and worked with GCC to evolve the concept.

The result was Ms Pac-Man, which featured new mazes and improved the unpredictability of the ghost enemies to make the game more challenging. Original character designs featured Ms Pac-Man with hair, but this was soon replaced with her famous bow.
description_for_label:
Ms Pac-Man is the first famous female game protagonist, but she started out as a male character. Designed by a group of Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) dropouts who started a company called the General Computer Corporation (GCC), Ms Pac-Man was originally a modification for the original Pac-Man, called Crazy Otto. Due to legal action by Atari, GCC presented their modification kit to the North American Pac-Man distributor, who purchased it and worked with GCC to evolve the concept.

The result was Ms Pac-Man, which featured new mazes and improved the unpredictability of the ghost enemies to make the game more challenging. Original character designs featured Ms Pac-Man with hair, but this was soon replaced with her famous bow.
